Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Mechanisms That Link Conflict and Sleep Over Time

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Among adults who co-sleep with a partner, the quality of their sleep is strongly related to the amount of conflict in their relationships. People report worse sleep after conflict and more conflict after poor sleep. However, little is known about why poor sleep and interpersonal conflict are related or what factors might increase or decrease the connection. Both interpersonal conflict and poor sleep are associated with chronic stress, reduced immune function, shorter lifespan, and lower life satisfaction. They also impose staggering social and economic burdens, costing the nation hundreds of billions of dollars every year and negatively impacting the development of children exposed to parental conflict. Understanding what drives links between conflict and sleep is necessary to reduce these tolls. This research will examine behavioral, emotional, cognitive, and psychophysiological pathways through which sleep and conflict are related over time. It will also test whether poor self-regulation (difficulty adjusting behavior, emotions, and thoughts in response to environmental demands) renders some people more vulnerable to negative links between conflict and sleep. The discovery of how specific relationship processes can promote sleep quality and how aspects of sleep quality can reduce conflict severity and frequency could inform intervention strategies for therapists working with distressed couples. The discovery that self-regulation (a resource that can be strengthened through training and practice) can protect people from these negative effects would advance intervention and prevention, ultimately impacting public health, the economy, and child development.

This multi-method longitudinal study of 200 couples will investigate how observed and self-reported features of conflict are associated with fluctuations in objective and subjective measures of sleep quality over time. The study has three objectives. The first is to determine how partners' behavioral, emotional, and physiological stress responses to a lab-based conflict are associated with their own and each other's typical sleep quality. The second is to determine the direction of links between specific features of conflict and sleep over time, using cross-lagged analysis of dyadic daily diary and sleep assessments collected at home over 14 days. The third objective is to determine whether developmentally organized markers of self-regulation (attachment, heart rate variability, rumination, and post-conflict recovery behavior) moderate links between conflict and sleep over time. This study will contribute to science by advancing a theoretically-derived model of individual differences in interpersonal stress reactivity and regulation that affect behavior in two critically important social contexts. Additionally, this project will provide training for the next generation of STEM scientists by engaging diverse undergraduate women in mentored research and discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Overview

This project collected longitudinal data from a diverse sample of adult cohabiting couples from urban, suburban, and rural communities in western Massachusetts, U.S. Between March 2017-June 2019, 208 couples (416 individuals) completed online surveys, a visit to the laboratory at Mount Holyoke College, and a 14-day at-home assessment of sleep, daily conflict, and stress. In April 2020, 241 of these participants reported on their experiences during the initial COVID-19 pandemic surge. The goal of this research was to understand how interpersonal conflict in romantic relationships is associated with sleep and stress over time. Analysis of these data to date have resulted in several discoveries relevant to interpersonal relationships, sleep, and stress. 

Key Findings

First, attachment style was associated with self-reported and objectively measured sleep quality. Higher anxious attachment was associated with worse self-reported sleep quality. Additionally, people’s romantic partner’s attachment style had important associations with their own sleep quality. Less anxious and less avoidant people slept significantly worse when their partners were highly avoidant, while highly avoidant people slept somewhat better when their partners were also highly avoidant. This project also found that people who were more anxiously attached and who argued with their partners more frequently slept worse than anxiously attached people who reported fewer arguments. These findings show that frequent interpersonal conflict may take a significant toll on anxiously attached people’s sleep, suggesting that they are more susceptible to dysregulation in the context of higher interpersonal stress.

This study also generated important findings regarding how people responded to the stressors of the initial COVID-19 pandemic surge in 2020. Participants who had experienced more adverse childhood experiences (ACEs; e.g., parental divorce, parental substance use, physical or sexual abuse, neglect) reported more negative life disruptions during the COVID-19 pandemic (e.g., financial and employment problems, social isolation, and emotional and physical health problems). In turn, exposure to more negative pandemic disruptions was associated with increased stress and depressive symptoms over time and decreased relationship satisfaction over time. These findings suggest that exposure to ACEs is an important risk factor in how people experienced the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Key Outcomes

Findings to date were shared with scientific communities and the public through several conference presentations and publications and have been featured in two episodes of the Relationship Matters podcast. Dr. Haydon (the principal investigator) also presented results to a group of occupational, marital, and family therapists to inform them of recent discoveries and discuss insights emerging from research and applied clinical efforts. The initial findings from this project provided new evidence that may inform intervention and prevention, ultimately impacting public health, the economy, and child development.

In addition to scientific discoveries, this project had significant impacts on education and training. Located at Mount Holyoke College, this project delivered rigorous in-depth training for 24 undergraduate women research assistants, including students from diverse and underrepresented backgrounds (e.g., students of color, students from low-income families, and first-generation college students). Students were trained and mentored in data collection, cleaning, and analysis and several were supported in their first research presentations at professional conferences and their first publications in refereed journals. Many of these students have since entered graduate programs or pursued post-baccalaureate research associate positions, demonstrating the lasting impact of this project on the next generation of STEM professionals.
